case_vignette: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he has excessively dry skin. His mother says that he has had dry, scaly skin since he was 6 months old. She says it is worse in winter and better in summer. There is no associated itching, redness, or discharge. Examination reveals generalized fine scales with coarse skin all over the body, except in the skin creases of the neck and in the cubital and popliteal fossae (see image). There are multiple papular elevations at the base of hair follicles and darkening of the palmar and plantar creases.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have really dry and scaly skin all over my body, especially in the winter.
How old are you?
I'm 8 years old.
Have you had any similar skin issues in the past?
Yes, I've had dry, scaly skin since I was a baby, about 6 months old.
Has anyone in your family had similar skin issues?
The case vignette does not provide information about my family's medical history or if anyone else has had similar skin issues.
I see. Have you been using any medications for your dry skin?
No, the vignette doesn't mention me using any medications for my skin.
**Final Diagnosis:** Atopic Dermatitis
